dict.string: w: d-dimensional vector called the weight vector
E.g., for d=2, y=0 is a straight line
Decision boundary y(x)=0 corresponds to a (d-1)-dimensional hyperplane in d-dimensional x-space.
Proof: If xA and xB are two points on the hyperplane, then y(xA)=0=y(xB) and so, using (3.1), we have wT(xB-xA)=0.
w is normal to any vector lying in the hyperplane.
If x is a point on the hyperplane then the normal distance from the origin to the hyperplane is given by wTw/||w|| or -w0/||w||. The bias x0 determines the position of the hyperplane in x-space.
Geometric interpretation of decision boundary
Define new (d+1)-dimensional vector w=(w0, w) and x=(1, x).
We can interpret the decision boundary y(x)=0 as a d-dimensional hyperplane which passes through the origin in (d+1)-dimensional x-space.
Neural network diagram
Discriminant function: y(x) = wTx+w0 (3.1)
Using yk(x)=yj(x) and (3.1)
Decision boundary: (wk-wj)Tx + (wk0 - wj0)=0
If x is a point on the hyperplane then the normal distance from the origin to the hyperplane is given by.
Geometric interpretation of decision boundary
Neural network diagram
A new point x is assigned to class Ck if yk(x) > yj(x) for all j not equal k.
Linear combination of input variables
Motivations of the use of sigmoid function
E.g., logistic regression
Transforming the linear combination with a non-linear function (activation function)
Transforming the input variables with fixed non-linear functions before forming the linear combination - generalized linear discriminants
Techniques for determining weight values
Single layer networks
